But I believe that patients and family members have an important role to play</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:07:13 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11915008.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11914807</guid><link>http://news.nationalpost.com/health/five-reasons-we-regain-weight?__lsa=f370-1302</link><title>Five reasons we regain weight</title><description>No one ever says, "I want to lose 30 pounds, keep it off briefly, then gain it all back, with some extra pounds for good measure." But that's exactly what happens to most people who lose weight.</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:22:25 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11914799.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11912045</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/people+deemed+overweight+actually+have+lower+risk+dying+than+those/11912045/story.html</link><title>People deemed overweight may have a lower risk of dying, study says</title><description>People who have a Body Mass Index of 27 &#8212; officially classed as overweight &#8212; now have the lowest risk of dying from any condition</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:00:50 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11912047.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /><a10:link rel="external" type="text/html" title="People deemed overweight may have a lower risk of dying, study says" href="http://news.nationalpost.com/health/overweight-people-may-actually-have-a-lower-risk-of-death-than-those-who-are-healthy-study-says" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11914587</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/more+funding+devoted+treating+cancers+with+campaigns+than+those/11914587/story.html</link><title>More funding devoted to treating cancers with PR campaigns</title><description>Lung malignancies, for instance, account for 40 per cent of Canadians who die from cancer &#8211; yet just 15 per cent of North American clinical trials focus on the disease</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 22:42:57 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11914710.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /><a10:link rel="external" type="text/html" title="More funding devoted to treating cancers with PR campaigns" href="http://news.nationalpost.com/health/more-funding-devoted-to-treating-cancers-with-pr-campaigns-than-those-with-higher-death-rates-study" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11911806</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/throwing+punch+parkinson+disease/11911806/story.html</link><title>Throwing a punch at Parkinson’s disease</title><description>I have Parkinson's disease, and it causes my body to just freeze up. Weirdly enough, boxing helps me get unstuck.</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 16:59:46 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11911807.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /><a10:link rel="external" type="text/html" title="Throwing a punch at Parkinson’s disease" href="http://news.nationalpost.com/health/throwing-a-punch-at-parkinsons" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11912093</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/study+asks+much+folic+acid+cause+autism/11912093/story.html</link><title>A study asks: Too much folic acid a cause of autism?</title><description>For decades, pregnant women have been advised to take folic acid to help prevent certain birth defects. But a new study suggests it may be possible to get too much of a good thing</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 19:01:41 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11912094.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /><a10:link rel="external" type="text/html" title="A study asks: Too much folic acid a cause of autism?" href="http://news.nationalpost.com/health/a-study-asks-too-much-folic-acid-a-cause-of-autism" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11912211</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/brain+scans+find+protein+marker+alzheimers+decline/11912211/story.html</link><title>Brain scans find protein a marker of Alzheimer's decline</title><description>WASHINGTON - Scientists are peeking inside living brains to watch for the first time as a toxic duo of plaques and tangles interact to drive Alzheimer's disease &#8212; and those tangles may predict early symptoms, a finding with implications for better treatments.</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 21:00:58 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11912212.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11910387</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/scientist+needs+patients+help+launch+budget+baby+making+clinic/11910387/story.html</link><title>Scientist needs patients to help launch budget baby-making clinic in Calgary</title><description>100 'founder patients' sought to pay $4,000 for innovative treatment that will regularly cost about $6,500 &#8212; about half the pricetag of conventional IVF</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 14:57:23 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11910388.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /><a10:link rel="external" type="text/html" title="Scientist needs patients to help launch budget baby-making clinic in Calgary" href="http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/want-ivf-for-half-the-price-scientist-needs-you-to-help-launch-a-calgary-clinic-for-baby-making-on-a-budget" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11907832</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/canada+sees+progress+obesity+overweight+rates+drop+among+children/11907832/story.html</link><title>Canada sees progress in war on obesity as overweight rates drop among children</title><description>However, while both weight and body-mass-index scores decreased overall, the proportion of children classed as obese held steady, at about 13 per cent</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 13:57:23 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11907833.jpg" type="image/jpeg" /><a10:link rel="external" type="text/html" title="Canada sees progress in war on obesity as overweight rates drop among children" href="http://news.nationalpost.com/health/canada-sees-progress-in-war-on-obesity-as-overweight-rates-drop-among-children" /></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">tag:www.theprovince.com:content=11909071</guid><link>http://www.theprovince.com/health/just+like+magic+show+rare+identical+quadruplets+born+alberta/11909071/story.html</link><title>Rare identical quadruplets born to Alberta couple</title><description>Naturally conceived girls are the fifth set of quadruplets to be born in Alberta since 2004. Experts explain babies’ first words</title><description>There's little debate that mama and dada are often among baby's first utterances. restoring the body's ability to repair itself'</description><source>Health</source><pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 19:51:24 Z</pubDate><enclosure url="http://www.theprovince.com/cms/binary/11886420.jpg"
